title: Microsoft 365
text: Hide and Seek!

title: Microsoft 365
text:
Lesson Objectives

Articulate the importance of Microsoft 365 to the Army
Differentiate the core Microsoft 365 products
Distinguish when to use OneDrive, Teams, or SharePoint to share data
Use OneDrive, Outlook, Teams, OneNote, Word, PowerPoint, and Office.com to accomplish a variety of tasks

title: Microsoft 365
text:
Discussion

What can I do with Word? Excel?
Can I use PowerPoint for anything other than briefings?
When is it appropriate to use Teams vs Outlook?
What is the difference between OneDrive and SharePoint? Which one is better?
What is a quad chart? Why does the Army care?
Is Microsoft better or worse than Google? Why?

title: Welcome to CY105
text:
CY105 Course Objectives

Examine legal, ethical, professional, and security issues associated with the cyber domain.
Function as an ethical, secure, and competent user in West Point’s immersive technology and cyber environment.
Apply sequential logic, control flow statements, and code libraries using a modern programming language, algorithmic thinking, and a problem-solving process.
Describe how data flows from data sources across air, land, sea, and cyberspace to form a network of information that is constantly being tracked and exploited by allies, adversaries, and third parties.
Describe and explore the opportunities and challenges presented by artificial intelligence in the modern world.

title: Welcome to CY105
text:
What’s in it for you?





“Information superiority is the operational advantage derived from the ability to collect, process, and disseminate an uninterrupted flow of information while exploiting or denying an adversary’s ability to do the same…”
FM 3-0, Operations, February 2008​




information makes you smarter
access to information makes you an effective leader
increase your confidence with IT systems
help you learn new IT concepts and systems​
protect yourself and your organization
foundational course for everyone

title: Welcome to CY105

title: Welcome to CY105
text:
Generative AI Tools

AI tools may be used to determine what AI-generated responses to a particular prompt may look like either before or after issuing an assignment.
These responses can be compared to cadets’ submissions using MOSS or zyLabs Similarity Checker to determine if a cadet’s submission contains features that suggest unauthorized or undocumented AI use.

title: Welcome to CY105
text: Next Class

title: Computing Fundamentals
text: This course introduces the fundamentals of computing and cyberspace and blends theoretical knowledge with the practical application of computer hardware, software (programming), and cyberspace. Emphasis is placed on developing critical thinking skills and understanding the legal, ethical, and professional considerations as well as the challenges, opportunities, and attributes of the cyber domain.

title: Computing Fundamentals
text:
Course Objectives

Examine legal, ethical, professional, and security issues associated with the cyber domain.
Function as an ethical, secure, and competent user in West Point’s immersive technology and cyber environment.
Apply sequential logic, control flow statements, and code libraries using a modern programming language, algorithmic thinking, and a problem-solving process.
Describe how data flows from data sources across air, land, sea, and cyberspace to form a network of information that is constantly being tracked and exploited by allies, adversaries, and third parties.
Describe and explore the opportunities and challenges presented by artificial intelligence in the modern world.

title: Computing Fundamentals
text:
Additional Instruction

Complete required readings and in-class exercises.
Book a meeting
Come prepared with specific questions and bring your computer!

Plan ahead and do not wait until the assignment due date! Note that once you setup a meeting for additional instruction, it becomes your assigned place of duty. If you cannot make it, please notify me as early as possible.

title: Computers and Data
text:
Welcome!

Inside the “3 Billion People” National Public Data Breach
haveibeenpwned.com

title: Computers and Data
text:
Lesson Objectives

Define data, how it differs from information, and its forms: analog and digital.
Define what a computer is, define common types of computers, and distinguish their uses from each other. 
Describe how digital data is quantified and represented on computers.
Describe how computers process and store data.
Learn how to read an ASCII table.

title: Computers and Data
text:
Information



Data = facts

measurements
statistics
values

Information

data processed, organized, or structured in a meaningful way

title: Computers and Data
text:
Analog vs Digital Data



Analog

Continuous data
Smooth, unbroken line
Speed, temperature
More accurate
Harder to store, manipulate, and transmit

Digital

Discrete data
Staircase
e.g. ACFT score table
Easier to store, manipulate, and transmit

title: Computers and Data
text:
Analog to Digital

Video: Analog vs Digital

title: Computers and Data
text:
Computers are Everywhere

Embedded computers: inside of other electronic devices, usually not visible from the outside

title: Computers and Data
text:
Microcontrollers



Smallest processor
Run exactly one program
Can run on battery power
Bluefruit!

title: Computers and Data
text:
Mobile Computers

What are they?



Laptops, tablets, smartphones
Can run multiple programs at once
Designed for portability - battery power

title: Computers and Data
text:
Desktops and Servers



What about these?



Most powerful computers
Can run multiple programs at once
Designed for performance
Typically plugged into a power source

title: Computers and Data
text:
Check on Learning


What is information?
What is a microcontroller?
Is microcontroller a general-purpose computer?
Is calculator a general-purpose computer?
Is a smartphone a general-purpose computer?

title: Computers and Data
text:
Types of Devices


Input


Keyboard
Mouse
Touchscreen
Microphone
Camera



Output


Monitor
Printer
Speaker



Peripheral

Connect through expansion slots
Greatly expand computer capabilities



Graphics card (GPU)
Network card

title: Computers and Data
text:
Central Processing Unit (CPU)



Cache: small, fast memory


Reads instructions from memory
Performs logical and mathematical operations
Writes results back to memory

title: Computers and Data
text:
Storage



Cache
RAM
Hard Drive

title: Computers and Data
text:
The Bus



electronic conduit, connects all components together inside the computer

title: Computers and Data
text:
Scenario
Power Outage

You are working on a paper in the middle of the night. Suddenly, a powerful thunderstorm appears in the area and you lose power.
Suppose you are working on a desktop computer. What happens to your paper? What data is lost?
How does the above answer change if you were working on a laptop? What are some advantages/disadvantages of autosave?

Data Security

Your friend is thinking about making some extra cash by selling their computer. What advice would you give them so their personal data does not get stolen?
What concrete steps that you would recommend they take?
Any components worth removing or keeping? How does your answer change if it is a phone, laptop or desktop?

title: Computers and Data
text:
Binary

Light switch = on or off
Only two values: 0 and 1
Bit = binary digit
Byte = 8 bits
[How exactly does binary code work?] (https://www.youtube.com/embed/wgbV6DLVezo)
Representing Numbers and Letters with Binary



Bit = light switch, off or on

title: Computers and Data
text:
Hexadecimal

Base 16 => 0-9, A-F
4 bits = 1 hex digit
Easier for humans to read



16 objects, unique labels
board example

title: Computers and Data
text: Conversion: Decimal - Binary - Hexadecimal

title: Computers and Data
text: Quantifying Data Sizes

title: Computers and Data
text:
ASCII

American Standard Code for Information Interchange
7-bit encoding scheme
95 printable characters, 33 control characters
Invented in 1963; last updated in 1986

title: Computers and Data
text:
File Extensions

Indicate what type of data is in a file
Help computer deduce how to process and interpret
Not foolproof, but helpful
File headers provide more information
Examples: .docx, .xlsx, .pptx, .jpg, .mp4, .py

title: Computers and Data
text: Other Encoding Schemes

title: Computers and Data
text:
Image Encoding

Video: Images, Pixels and RGB
Digital Compression

How do computers process data?
What is the difference between RAM and a hard drive?
List and describe popular encoding schemes including RGB, ASCII, and Unicode
